ratings.question_text: Overall, how would you rate the workload of this course in comparison to other Yale courses you have taken?
What is your overall assessment of this course?
Do you expect to use this class for credit toward your major, or toward a pre-professional program?

narratives.question_text: How would you summarize ECON 110 05 for a fellow student? Would you recommend ECON 110 05 to another student? Why or why not?
comments: Very chill professor, interesting reading list.Two five-page reading responses, two ten-page papers. All on whatever you want, which is pretty fun.Discussions were sometimes slow because our class size was small, but that could easily change.

This class is basically just a book club. Or maybe that's just how english classes work...The books are interesting, but class doesn't add anything. The grade is basically just the papers (2 4pg and 2 10 pg) and Berger is very into helping with them (and handing out A's if you let him guide you). There's a good deal of reading, but it's enjoyable and a great way to procrastinate other classes. Class was small, only 6 or 7 people.

Overall it was a great experience! It was more than just a class on "end times" but also brought to light different issues and consequences of the apocalypse. I would definitely recommend this class to other students as it was an interesting experience and wasn't too demanding for a seminar.
I'd recommend it if students have an affinity for the material covered. I would say it was a very manageable workload and fairly engaging.
